properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected beginning this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday evening until Thursday morning. Locations: Great Northern Peninsula. Snowfall amounts: 10 to 15 cm (by midnight Wednesday night). Rainfall amounts: 5 to 10 mm (by early Thursday morning). Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over the Great Northern Peninsula late in the day on Wednesday with strengthening easterly winds. The snow is forecast to change to rain later Wednesday night and then taper to flurries by Thursday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-03T12:00:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 2, 2020 16:00 local Mountain time - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Golden due to high concentrations of dust that are expected to persist for the next 24 hours. This advisory will be updated tomorrow. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have underlying medical conditions such as breathing or lung conditions, hay fever, asthma or persons who react strongly to dust. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheeze, follow the advice of your health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-landwater/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-03T15:43:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-02T23:44:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1625545018.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southwesterly winds are expected to persist today. With periods of falling snow, blizzard conditions are again expected for much of the day. Winds should ease somewhat by this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T05:00:53-00:00

Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, mild temperatures and gusty winds are expected mid-week. Time span: Wednesday and Wednesday night. Locations: central and eastern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm (higher amounts possible over southern areas). Maximum wind gusts: southerly 70 to 100 km/h (strongest near the coast). Remarks: Rain will begin along the south coast of Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and is expected to spread over central and eastern parts of the island by early Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. The mild air combined with the rain could cause significant snowmelt and runoff. The rain is forecast to taper off Wednesday night. In addition, a period of strong southerly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday night. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-03T11:33:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-02T19:34:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4169373361.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, snow and strong winds expected later this week. Time span: Wednesday through Thursday. Locations: western and southwestern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm, with higher amounts along south coast (Wednesday). Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm or more (Thursday). Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 80 to 100 km/h (Wednesday). Remarks: Rain will begin over southwestern Newfoundland on Wednesday morning and is expected to spread up the west coast on Wednesday afternoon. The rain may be preceded by a short period of freezing rain over some areas, but temperatures are anticipated to rise quickly over most locations. Colder air will return Wednesday night, causing the rain to change to snow. Snow will then likely continue through Thursday and may be heavy over some areas, especially along the Long Range Mountains. In addition, a period of strong southeasterly winds is expected over most areas on Wednesday afternoon or evening. Gusty west to southwesterlies will then follow for Thursday. Localized flooding may occur in low lying areas. Where possible, ice and snow should be cleared from storm drains in advance of this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-03T11:42:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-02T19:43:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0765230476.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds through the Richardson Mountains will ease through the evening. Blizzard conditions are expected to perist until midnight before conditions improve. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather will occur over Eastern Quebec midweek... A low pressure system will intensify over the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Wednesday. It could bring heavy snowfall accompanied by strong winds giving blowing snow over the Gaspe Peninsula and the North Shore. The Southern Gaspe Peninsula could also see a period of freezing rain. Conditions should gradually improve on Thursday. The poor weather conditions could delay transportation. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plan. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T08:17:10-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A frontal system will move across northern BC tonight. Snow associated with the system will begin late this afternoon and taper off to flurries after midnight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing rain continues. Precipitation approaching from the southwest is occurring as freezing rain for some areas near the Ottawa River. The freezing rain may cause untreated surfaces such as roads, walkways and parking lots to become icy and slippery. There may be some impact on the commute home from work this afternoon. Precipitation is expected to change over to rain by this evening as temperatures inch above the zero degree mark. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T03:59:17-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold wind chill values will continue tonight and Tuesday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-03T14:25:09-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continues. An area of freezing rain is moving across Eastern Ontario, causing a thin glaze of ice to develop on untreated surfaces. The precipitation will change over to rain this evening as milder air arrives, increasing temperatures to above freezing. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
